STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 11, 2019
Debra Matthews
Children’s Center Wayne County
79 West Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48201
RE: License #: CB820201055
Children's Center Wayne Co.
79 W Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48202
Dear Ms. Matthews:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
04/08/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 An explanation why previous CAP have not been obtained and
maintained compliance for rules found in repeat noncompliance.
 Be signed and dated.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
George Winn, COO
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In one out of eight foster children service plans reviewed, one was late. The report
period was 7/9/18 – 10/6/18, the report was completed on 12/27/18, 82 days late.
In two of six independent living case records, one USP report dated 4/19/18 –
7/17/18 was 23 days late. Report dated 9/7/18 – 12/5/18 the report was late by 15
days.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL 2017 & INTERIM 2018
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
4

The agency is not consistent in uploading their documentation in MiSACWIS for
foster care, independent living and adoption programs. The documents are:
 Medical passports, no updates
 Unannounced home visits
 Foster parent training
 Updated service plans
 69b/69
 Family team meetings
 Parent agency treatment plans
 Foster care referral for adoption planning
 Quarterly adoption progress reports
 Uploading PATP’s timely
 Timely uploading of 612 and 3130’s
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM INTERIM 2018
ISEP. 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors),
and provided to the foster care provider.
Four of five child records reviewed did not show documentation that the medical
passport was signed by/ provided the foster parent/caregiver as required by the
standard.
Four of five open child records reviewed did not showed documentation the child’s
medical passport was updated quarterly.
One of six case record in adoption records reviewed, one of the immunization
records was not signed by the doctor or foster parent.
5

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
722-06B pg. 2-6
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out-lined in the following tables…
In five of forty – two service plans reviewed, five was not consistent with
documentation of an FTM for the service plan period. Three of the records did not
have documentation that an FTM was completed for the USP’s reporting period.
Two records had no timeframes for the youth goals. Some FTM’s did not include all
of the children’s in the home names on the FTM report and/or activity reports
documented in MiSACWIS.
DHHS Policy Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction
FOM 722-06i
Page 10
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time.
In one out of eight case records reviewed, one did not show documentation of sibling
contact.
DHHS Policy Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
FOM 722-9
Supervisory approval
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
6

In two of eight foster care case records reviewed, two did not have the supervisor
signature within fourteen days after the face to face meeting with the caseworker.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contacts.
FOM 722-6 H
Unannounced Home visit.
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the
placement every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted
in the social work contacts of the case service plan.
In two of eight foster care records reviewed, two did not have documentation of a
quarterly unannounced home visit to the licensed foster parent/caregiver’s home.
In two of eight foster care records reviewed, two did not have documentation of a
monthly face to face visit with the child in the foster home.
DHHS Policy Transfer of student records
FOM 723
The caseworker must request student records using the DHHS -
942, Education Record Release. Request records should
include, but not limited to grades/unofficial transcripts.
In one out of eight foster care case records, one did not have a current update of the
child’s recent school record.
DHHS Policy F o s t e r c a re – Parent agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722 – 8C A greement.
Signature: when completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate including those of parent(s) guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHHS office designee.
In two out of eight case records reviewed, two were missing the signatures and the
dates for the foster parents on the PATP.
In four of forty -eight service plans reviewed, four were unsigned or had no dates.
In five out of forty – eight service plans reviewed, five did not have the boxes
checked stating the child, foster parent, independent living youth agrees with the
agreement.
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
DHHS Policy Health Documentation
FOM 801
All health requirements are to be documented and maintained
as follows: DHHS 1643, Psychotropic medication informed
consent.
One out of eight case records reviewed did not have documentation in MISACWIS of
the child Abilify and Lamictal.
DHHS Policy P e r s onnel Training.
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors who
have access to CW – CHRI are required to complete security
awareness training (SAT). Training will be available on the
Learning management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel
and contractors with access to this system.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes the SAT. DCWL consultants will monitor
completion of SAT as part of the annual licensing audit.
CI-182a was released to the field in December of 2016
advising all current employees with access to CHRI to
complete SAT training no later than 02/10/2017. All other
employees hired after December of 2016 were required to
complete SAT according to the policy.
There were thirteen employees with access to criminal record history information
(CHRI) since the last inspection. Based on the LMS transcript for employees, all
thirteen employees was found to not have completed the SAT recertification training.
The recertification Communication Issuance 19-023 was not issued to private
agencies until 03/11/2019.
8

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
It was reported that the foster parent physically assaulted her biological daughter.
The agency found the foster parent in non-compliance with R9404 Behavior
management (3) foster parent shall not use corporal punishment. Evaluation
number 2019C0626328. The agency reported the foster parent did not take
responsibility for actions and another governmental agency made a substantiation
and, the agency recommended revocation of the foster home license. The agency
handling of the special evaluations appears appropriate.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the 07/10/2018 renewal inspection
report. The corrective action plan was accepted on 7/30/2018. The non -
compliances were R400.12404 (7, b) Placement, R400.12418 (2, b) Development of
service plan, ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS and ISEP 6.18 Relative foster parent licensing
timeliness. The agency affectively addressed two non-compliances as there were
no repeat violations. However, there are two repeated non – compliances for this
reporting period.
VII. DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #2:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
9

Safety Alert #3:
Concern: Licensing process took too long (almost a year).
Foster parent do not have a medical passport for either of the children
Resolution: The agency listed a timeline of contacts regarding the timeline of the
licensure. The list included the dates of 10/01/17 to 4/20/18 where barriers included
applicant not submitting paperwork timely, fingerprinting showing MiSACWIS history,
information not completed on forms, as well as incorrect forms that had to be resend to
the applicant and receiving the wrong information. After all of the information were
completed and explained, the DCWL 3130 was sent to DCWL for Licensure. The
applicant was license on 07/12/2018. See Safety Alert for a detail timeline.
Resolution: The agency submitted the signature pages of the medical passports which
are also uploaded in MiSACWIS. It should be noted that the agency was in violation for
not submitting timely medical passports but not on this case.
Safety Alert #4:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #5:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #6:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
Safety Alert #7:
Concern: No safety concerns was reported for this home.
Resolution: No resolution required.
10

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Children’s Center of Wayne
will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
04/11/2019
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 12, 2019
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
